page.title: 03LIFEBOAT MEMORIES SWANAGE
page.content: In 1916 the lifeboat was called the Herbert Sturmey. She was a sailing and rowing boat with 12 oars built in the Isle of Wight. In 1928 a new motor boat was used and because she was longer than the previous boat a new slipway had to be built and the lifeboat house was altered. This boat was used right through the Second World War although the maroons were not allowed to be let off. Telephones were very limited so the coxswain had to knock men up all over Swanage when they were needed. Then he had to get back to the lifeboat. She was not allowed to go to sea until every authority was notified. It was very important to inform the sentries on the cliff when the lifeboat was going to be launched otherwise it might be mistaken for an enemy ship.
